body:
I've been using neovim's terminal feature extensively lately (notice all my bug reports :P) and I had a couple really neat ideas that I think would be a must have feature for anyone who uses ssh and neovim. 

First in the neovim terminal if you are sshed onto a server, if you type `nvim file` instead of opening a new neovim instance on the server it pipes back the data to your already neovim. This would make editing over SSH very seamless. You already have the terminal open and maybe you were doing something and bam if you type nvim you can edit now in your already open instance (access to clipboard etc).

I know about netrw's ability to edit files over the network but it would be really nice if it was seamless. I have to type `e scp://server/pathtofile` which is really annoying but a simple `nvim file` would make it much easier. 

Second is either syncing the working directories of the terminals with neovim similar to `set autochdir` or to be able to again pipe straight into the open neovim instance from the terminal. 

These are ideas I want to implement myself but I wanted some input first.

edit: nvm I'm never gonna have the time to implement all this. Sorry!

comment_data.body:
>  if you type nvim file instead of opening a new neovim instance on the server it pipes back the data to your already neovim

With the client-server architecture this should be relatively straightforward, but the user experience of connecting a local nvim to a remote nvim server may not be seamless. I would look at how people in tmux-land approach [remote clipboard](https://www.google.com/search?q=tmux%20remote%20clipboard). What can we learn there? 

> syncing the working directories of the terminals with neovim similar to set autochdir

See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/2252
Ah great that is already done (opening a file in vim from a terminal buffer) and the directory syncing is already open. I'll take a look at tmux's remote clipboard.

Well it seems we need to get neovim to listen on some port and then when sshing onto the remote host we need to set up some remote forwards so that programs on the remote host can communicate with neovim on the local host. Shouldn't be too difficult to do.

@nhooyr I would not say this is the best idea in the given circumstances. There is already a communication channel open and it may be used: just use special escape sequences like `{special escape}{length}{contents}` to communicate in both directions.

One such variant is creating a special API which can basically do four things: tell local* Neovim to open file with given name (transformed into something like `termfile://{terminal buffer ID}/{received file name}`, `{received file name}` is nothing other then identifier for remote), tell remote Neovim to write file with given name, tell remote Neovim to send special file associated with the given file name contents (I mean swap and persistent undo files) and tell remote Neovim to write special file associated with the given file name contents.

It is also possible to leave only “remote write file” command, while “remote to local” communication would be “local do {usual msgpack API call}”, “remote write file” command will be issued by `BufWriteCmd` based on information provided by remote via API calls.

These variants though take over the terminal session, to make them not do this one needs a wrapper so that channel will look like `local <> :terminal <> [ssh <> ]remote <> shell` where remote will parse only special escape sequences and take over any `nvim` launches in the shell, otherwise leaving communications untouched.

\* local: Neovim which has `:terminal` open. remote: Neovim which is opened in `:terminal`. Presence or absence of ssh is irrelevant.

@nhooyr Problem with Neovim listening on some port is that it is not uncommon that local Neovim is e.g. behind NAT. Outgoing communication from server to client are not easy, so using existing ssh channel is better.
@nhooyr Though maybe this is because I do not know how to set up these “forwards”.

@ZyX-I it should work perfectly. NAT doesn't matter with ssh's remote forwarding. It uses the existing SSH connection. It will be much easier. I just finished a big exam so I have lots of free time, I'll implement it and then report back. I'm not sure what you meant by the escape sequences but trust me, SSH remote forwarding is much much more simple.
Got it to work perfectly. I'm gonna create a pull request on mhinz/neovim-remote with my changes.

Well before I do that I thought I'd show them here.

First what I did was set the NVIM_LISTEN_ADDRESS on both machines as so in my zshrc

``` zsh
export NVIM_LISTEN_ADDRESS=127.0.0.1:6666
```

Next I added this rule under `~/.ssh/config` for the server I will ssh to.

``` ssh
Host ezekiel
RemoteForward 6666 localhost:6666
```

What this essentially does is say that any connections on the remote host (ezekiel) on port 6666 will be forwarded over the ssh connection and piped to the local port on the local machine at port 6666. Since I have neovim configured to listen locally on port 6666 any connections on the remote port 6666 will actually redirect to my local neovim. 

Lastly I created this very small script for testing.

``` python
#!/usr/bin/python3
from neovim import attach
import sys, os.path

args = sys.argv[1:]
if not args:
    print("Usage: nvimt <filename> ...")
    sys.exit(1)

addr = os.environ["NVIM_LISTEN_ADDRESS"]
if not addr:
    # TODO: Open a new nvim instance if no addr
    sys.exit(2)

ip, separator, port = addr.rpartition(':')
assert separator
port = int(port)
nvim = attach("tcp", path=ip, port=port)

def normalizePath(name):
    path = os.path.abspath(name).replace(" ", "\\ ")
    if os.path.isdir(name):
        path += "/"
    return path

def openFiles():
    #TODO check if ssh
    for x in args:
        nvim.command("drop scp://ezekiel/{}".format(normalizePath(x)))

openFiles()
```

It only works over ssh atm though with minor modifications I could get it to change the path depending on if its running locally or remote but as it was only for testing ssh and I plan on adding this functionality to #mhinz/neovim-remote I didn't bother as its trivial.

`let g:netrw_silent=1` is also very useful as it prevents the annoying press key to continue messages.
https://youtu.be/T524067emgk here is a video of me using it. I apologize for the background noise, still at school. Also might have to wait for the quality to get higher.

@nhooyr Variant with escape sequences and wrapper requires no configuration except running shell in wrapper and supports any number of Neovim instances. I do not see this with ssh forwarding.

Also your variant requires passwordless ssh or it will bother user with password prompts because ssh connection is recreated by netrw when opening using `scp://`.

Also I do not see how you determine host name and port for `scp://`, it definitely should not always be `scp://ezekiel/`.

---

I do not see what is the problem with escape sequences. Just in place of writing something to socket you write something to `stdout`, but prefix it with `{escape sequence}{legth}{separator}` (e.g. `<Esc>[Nvim:1024:{contents}`), same for answers. The only configuration you need to do here is run shell like `nvim-wrapper zsh` to make answers sent by the local Neovim to the remote be catched by the wrapper in place of confusing currently running application (also to open something with local Neovim `nvim` needs to be a script which notifies wrapper). Though if you run tmux or screen on remote wrapper additionally needs to escape everything to pass it through tmux/screen unchanged.

@nhooyr You forgot that keys can be passworded? I also do not use them _always_.

About code: code needs to be written once, and written by the Neovim developers. 2 lines per Neovim instance are needed each time you think you need to use more then current amount of instances, NEOVIM_LISTENT_ADDRESS _cannot_ be set like this in zshrc if you ever want to have more then one instance, so it is far more lines then one, and again written by _each_ **_user**_. Also questions with hosts. Also if I am not mistaking to localhost:6666 (or whatever port) can connect _any_ user on the computer, so it is insecure if one computer is used by more then one user.
Yea I definitely agree with you. Escape sequences are a much better solution. My bad. But at least until then, this is a easy solution that works.

@nhooyr On the local side you need modifications to `terminal.c` and to libtermkey. Most likely also changes elsewhere, RPC code was mostly written by @tarruda. Ask @leonerd regarding libtermkey and which escape sequences can be picked up, also whether there is better scheme then mine (I mean, `{escape}{length}{content}`, maybe there is a reason to prefer `{escape}{escaped content}{escape 2}` or something like this). Wrapper can be written in anything. BufWriteCmd (assuming it tells wrapper to write something) is fine with VimL, but needs to use `jobsend()` with terminal job ID.

I have also seen in http://invisible-island.net/xterm/ctlseqs/ctlseqs.html thing like “privacy message”, but have no idea WTF it is. Maybe it can (or even should) be used for our purposes, maybe it must not be used for this.

You can use ssh master connections to avoid retyping passwords (It is also more efficient), and I'm pretty sure you can open pipes through them without relying on local localhost security. But this still requires configuration, so escape sequences would be the simplest zero-config solution.

@ZyX-I I'd suggest using an OSC or similar sequence here, rather than a "raw" escape. Those already have a standard multiplexing and termination arrangement, so it should be relatively straightforward to have that integrate nicely up through the layers of code.

Ah yes I forgot about the ssh master connections. Funny thing is that I use them. sigh not sleeping for 30+ hours due to exams. ssh would also have permission problems, if you don't specify the host as logging in with root. Root login over ssh might be disabled etc. So yea escapes are way better.

I'll look through the code and try tomorrow. Ima sleep now.

@leonerd I see in http://invisible-island.net/xterm/ctlseqs/ctlseqs.html there is a thing named “Application Program Command”. Based on the name I can say this looks like what is needed. Thus I would suggest using `<Esc>_nvim:call:{msgpack base64}<Esc>\` for calling local API functions and reporting back responses, `<Esc>_nvim:write:{base64 file name}:{base64 file contents}<Esc>\` for telling wrapper to write file.

@ZyX-I Ahyes, an APC. That's the one I was thinking of.
Yes, an APC with a prefix of `nvim:` would be an excellent choice in this area. Do that.
Anyone else feel free to take this over, I'm not actively working on it.

@nhooyr I think we have a clear path forward with `$NVIM` env var and related stuff which will be introduced soon.

Edit (2023): $NVIM introduced in Nvim 0.8 https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/11009

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: terminal: tty RPC via APC ctrlseq
